text: Amelia Platts Boynton Robinson (August 18, 1911 â€“ August 26, 2015) was an American activist. She was a leader of the Civil Rights Movement in Selma, Alabama and a key figure in the 1965 march that became known as Bloody Sunday. In 1984 she became founding vice-president of the Schiller Institute working with Lyndon LaRouche. She was awarded the Martin Luther King, Jr. Freedom Medal in 1990. Robinson died in Montgomery, Alabama after suffering a series of strokes at the age of 104. ==References== Category:1911 births Category:2015 deaths Category:American activists Category:American centenarians Category:Deaths from stroke
title: Amelia Boynton Robinson
